Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent experimental progress in ultra-cold atomic/molecular gases and unconventional optical lattices has allowed us to push our exploration of the quantum world to a new limit, where a quantum many-particle system can be controlled and measured with exceptional precision. In modern quantum physics, one key development is the geometric/topological interpretation of quantum systems, from which topological field theory and the concept of topological states of matter are developed. The main objective of this investigation is to improve our knowledge on quantum topological states of matter by realizing, characterizing and understanding topologically-nontrivial quantum states in ultra-cold atomic gases. The physics principles revealed in this investigation may shed new light on other branches of scientific research including solid state physics, quantum information and quantum computation. In addition, the research plan contains an education component, which promotes awareness towards the research on novel quantum states and provides the general public, especially the next generation, novel knowledge on the future development of quantum computation. This setup offers an ideal platform for the investigation of quantum many-body systems and their topological properties.

The investigation contains a combined effort of theoretical and numerical studies utilizing modern theoretical techniques such as quantum field theory and exact numerical methods. By identifying topological states that are most suitable for realization in atomic systems, the study will provide direct guidance for experimental investigations. In addition, the unique properties of atomic gases will allow us to stabilize and to study novel topological states, which have never been realized in other systems. By studying these unconventional topological states, new principles of physics can emerge and will be studied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many-body physics studies collective motions in systems composed of large number of microscopic objects, e.g., liquids or gases formed by electrons or atoms, as well as systems made of synthetic particles. These systems contain huge numbers of particles, ranging from hundreds to billions and more. Because of collisions and interactions between particles, the motion and trajectory of each (microscopic) particle is extremely complicated and chaotic. Within the foreseeable future, even the most powerful supercomputers would not be capable of predicting these trajectories. However, if we zoom out and focus on collective behaviors, simple and universal (macroscopic) patterns emerge, in analogy to patterns formed by flocks of flying birds or schools of fish. These collective motions determine macroscopic properties of these systems. The objective of this project is to identify these collective motions in novel quantum many-body systems, from which new fundamental laws of physics shall emerge.

This research project mainly focuses on the following subjects

1.     Strongly-correlated topological states

Topological states of matter are a family of quantum materials, where the quantum ground-state wave-function contains a nontrivial topological structure. This topological structure often results in exotic quantum phenomena, impossible for conventional materials. In the current investigation about topological states of matter, one key focus is to combine nontrivial topology with strong interactions, known as strongly-correlated topological states, and new families of quantum states and new principles of physics are expected to emerge from the interplay between these two ingredients.

In this project, we proposed/studied several new quantum topological states, as well as experimental setups to realize/characterize these novel states of matter. In addition, utilizing novel numerical techniques (sign-problem-free quantum Monte Carlo methods), we studied many-body effects in strongly correlated topological phases and phase transitions and demonstrated a specific model system, where a theoretically proposed strongly-correlated topological state (topological Mott insulator) will emerge.  In our studies, we also developed several new and generic theoretical tools to characterize topological structure of quantum systems, such as quantum distance.

2.    Quantum phase transition and quantum critical criticality 

The phenomena of phase transitions are one of the main focus in the study of physics. A phase transition marks a special point, at which the physical properties of a system changes dramatically e.g., water turning into ice. In particle physics, the concept of phase transition also plays a very crucial role, through which fundamental particles obtains their masses, known as the Higgs mechanism.

In quantum many-body systems, a similar phenomenon can arise, known as quantum phase transitions. A quantum phase transition gives us a new knob to control/design material properties in quantum systems. The study about these phenomena has become one of the central focuses in quantum many-body systems since 1970s. In the past few decades, many different types of quantum phase transitions have been observed and studied. However, on the theoretical side, although extensive efforts have been devoted into this subject, our understanding about these quantum phenomena is still limited and many fundamental questions remain open. In particular, one of the biggest challenges is to understand quantum phase transitions and quantum criticality in systems with itinerant fermions. The quantum nature of these systems makes theoretical description and numerical simulations extremely challenging. To overcome this challenge, we developed an unbiased numerical method, which produces exact solutions for a variety of strongly-correlated quantum systems. These unbiased numerical results provide new insight and guidance for the study of quantum phase transitions in itinerant systems, paving the road for understanding the fundamental principles that govern these novel quantum systems.

3. Chiral spin liquids and Chern-Simons gauge theory

Chiral spin liquids are one of the most exotic states in quantum magnetism. It is a strongly-correlated topological state stabilized by geometric frustration. The exotic topological properties of this state have been well-understood theoretically. However, how to stabilize such an interesting state in a realistic (or semi-realistic) spin system remains an open question.

My coworkers and I developed a new theoretical approach to study frustrated spin systems utilizing a discretized Chern-Simons gauge theory that we developed. As the prototypical topological field theory, the Chern-Simons gauge theory has a deep and broad impact on a wide range of research in high-energy physics and condensed matter physics. Although well understood as a continuum field theory, there is very limited understanding on how to discretize this topological field theory on lattices or graphs. In this project, we found a generic method to construct discretized Chern-Simons gauge theory on lattices and graphs, utilizing the mathematical tool of algebra graph theory. Then we applied this new theory to study various frustrated spin systems and predicted two quantum systems, where chiral spin-liquid ground states shall emerge, and these theoretical predictions were supported by independent numerical studies.
